titleStmt.title: The young-mans complaint for the loss of his mistris. Young-men you see my fortune is such, I have lost my love by loving her too much: my fortune's bad as other young mens be, read but these lines, and you shall plainly see: I being bashful, she was something coy, I have lost my love, which should have been my joy. To an excellent new tune, I have lost my dear mistris.

The young-mans complaint for the loss of his mistris. Young-men you see my fortune is such, I have lost my love by loving her too much: my fortune's bad as other young mens be, read but these lines, and you shall plainly see: I being bashful, she was something coy, I have lost my love, which should have been my joy. To an excellent new tune, I have lost my dear mistris.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for F[rancis]. Coles, T[homas]. Vere, J[ohn]. Wright, and J[ohn]. Clarke.,

notesStmt.note: Verse: "Come hearken Apollo my pittiful groan ..."
Date, place of publication and publishers' names from Wing.
Reproduction of original in the Harvard University, Houghton Library.
